We can do both, and I'll keep fighting to make sure we do. 

For folks who want to read more, I'm linking the Medium post I wrote on this with @SenWarren. https://medium.com/@sentinasmith/our-plan-for-a-50-billion-child-care-bailout-4c3f0bef091f

I'll close by saying that this pandemic only exacerbated the childcare crisis. I've been working on this issue my entire time in the Senate‚Äîthe way we do childcare in this country needs an overhaul.

So let's make sure childcare survives this crisis AND fix the system long-term.

This isn't just the right thing to do, it's also an investment. Working moms contribute a huge amount to our workforce, if communities lack childcare, we are risking hamstringing our economic recovery.

With more emergency funding, we can avert this crisis. We can allow providers to keep staff on payroll, get PPE, and get assistance for other expenses needed to make childcare work.

Our bill has 50 billion in funding for this effect.

I'll touch on number two in this thread. Mass closures are a serious issue. Childcare has always had thin margins and an early survey indicated nearly half of all providers could not survive a two week shutdown.

Our plan has three pieces.  

1) Providing support to providers caring for the children of those fighting this pandemic on the frontlines. 
2) Preventing mass permanent closures in the childcare system.
3) Shoring up the system to make it work better in the future.

Also want to point out this crisis has been particularly hard on working moms. The @NYTimes had a feature on this recently, linked it here. 

So what can we do to ensure we have a robust childcare system in place when we can return to normal? https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/02/insider/virus-working-moms.html

Before I start, I'll just say this issue is personal. Both @SenWarren and I were young moms, our kids were always our first priority. 

When you‚Äôre a working mom, you need to feel confident that your kids are safe and cared for.

Parents raising kids during this pandemic are running into a major problem--our childcare system is at risk of collapsing. We've got two options, we can fix this crisis or ignore it. 

I teamed up with @SenWarren to make a plan to fix it. I want to share it with you. [THREAD]

The US played an important role in the signing of the Good Friday Agmt, an achievement that has been largely responsible for the relative peace over the last two decades. As we near the finish line of the Brexit process, I will continue to work to protect this vital peace accord.

I call on Prime Minister Johnson & the British Govt to respect international law by upholding the terms of this agreement. 
Ireland is one of the oldest & closest friends of the US, & the Irish people have been a crucial part of the fabric of our nation for nearly two centuries.

As part of the Withdrawal Agreement that saw the UK leave the EU earlier this year, the British Government agreed to the Northern Ireland Protocol, which would prevent the need for customs checks and a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

The resolution made it clear that for the US, a guarantor of the Good Friday Agreement, any bilateral trade deal w/the UK is contingent on protecting the historic peace accord and preventing the reintroduction of a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

Last year, the House of Representatives unanimously passed my resolution calling on the United Kingdom and European Union to ensure peace in Northern Ireland during Brexit negotiations. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ehf8hSQWoAEbiJi.jpg

It also directs the HHS Secretary to fund grants through the National Institutes of Health to conduct research on cardiovascular disease and other heart ailments among communities disproportionately affected by heart disease, such as South Asian populations living in the US.

My legislation addresses this by directing the HHS Secretary to create grants at the CDC to provide funding for community groups involved in South Asian heart health promotion and to develop culturally appropriate materials to promote heart health in the South Asian community.

South Asian Americans also have a much greater chance of having a heart attack before age 50 and have emerged as the ethnic group with the highest prevalence of Type 2 diabetes, which is a leading cause of heart disease. This morning I spoke to Ashley Dickenson with La Porte and Starke Hospitals in Northern Indiana. During this unprecedented time, keeping our hospitals solvent to continue to effectively serve the needs of Hoosiers is critical.

I cosponsored H.R. 945, the Mental Health Access Improvement Act.

Mental health treatment is a vital component of health care. Especially in the current pandemic, which has placed a strain on the mental health of many, promoting access to such treatment should be a priority.

This bipartisan legislation would make long-overdue improvements to the Fed Govt‚Äôs policies on marijuana research. It would advance the work of scientists and provide more reliable information about any benefits and harmful consequences that result from medicinal marijuana use.

I was an original cosponsor of H.R. 3797, the Medical Marijuana Research Act, and introduced the bill in past Congresses. 

Whatever our views on marijuana legalization as legislators, we all ought to support the collection of scientific data to guide our decisions.

The abuse of legal manufacturing and sales of opioids heavily contributed to the opioid crisis. H.R. 4812 would tighten restrictions on registrations to manufacture, distribute, or dispense them, helping to reduce opioid abuse as our country continues to face this crisis.

A @HouseCommerce markup today advanced several bills I introduced or cosponsored:

I introduced H.R. 4812, the Ensuring Compliance Against Drug Diversion Act, to limit the transfer of registrations to manufacture, distribute, or dispense controlled substances

The Delivering for America Act, which the House passed last month, requires that election mail be treated as first-class, restores mail service to previous levels, and provides $25 billion as unanimously requested by the bipartisan Postal Service Board of Governors.

The #HeroesAct, which the House passed nearly four months ago, includes $3.6 billion to help state and local governments pay for equipment and staff to safely administer the election. Republicans should agree to allocate these funds without further delay.

These actions left many voters, especially people of color, unable to exercise their right to vote. We cannot allow the pandemic to be used to continue or exacerbate the ugly history of voter suppression.

In Georgia, voters waited up to five hours to cast their ballots.  

In Texas, voters endured lines up to seven hours long.

In Florida, 112 polling places across the state were closed, moved, or consolidated.

Unfortunately, not every jurisdiction is following the CDC‚Äôs guidance. We saw what happened in this year‚Äôs primary elections in states that reduced the number of polling places and did not have adequate alternatives to in-person voting.

CDC voting guidance includes 3 elements:

1. Alternatives to in-person voting, including voting by mail.

2. Increasing the number of polling locations + extending hours for early voting.

3. Maintaining or increasing the total number of polling places available on Election Day.

Update: HR 4447 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 8121 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 6435 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 2610 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 8132 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 8128 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 8134 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4439 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4499 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 5572 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 5469 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 7293 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 3539 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 1109 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4861 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 2519 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4806 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 3797 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4812 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 3878 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 2466 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 2281 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 5373 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Next up is HR 5373, the United States Anti-Doping Agency Reauthorization Act, introduced by @RepThompson, @RepBillJohnson and @RepDianaDeGette. Update: HR 7948 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 3131 was favorably reported, as amended, to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 5855 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4764 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 4078 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.

Update: HR 8158 was favorably reported to the House by a voice vote.
